    <div id="readme" class="blob instapaper_body">
    <article class="markdown-body entry-content" itemprop="mainContentOfPage"><table data-table-type="yaml-metadata">
  <thead>
  <tr>
  <th>title</th>

  </thead>
  <tbody>
  <tr>
  <td><div>README</div></td>

  <td><div>Jarrett Byrnes</div></td>

  <td><div>December 10, 2014</div></td>

  <td><div>md_document</div></td>
  </tr>
  </tbody>
</table><h2>
<a id="user-content-a-library-to-examine-change-in-sea-surface-temperatures" class="anchor" href="#a-library-to-examine-change-in-sea-surface-temperatures" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>A library to examine change in Sea Surface Temperatures</h2>

<p>This library was developed following my own interest in replicating some of the analyses from Burrows et al. 2011 for SST change and climate velocity using the 
Met Office Hadley Centre Sea Surface Temperature 1.1 dataset, available at <a href="http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/hadobs/hadisst/data/download.html">http://www.metoffice.gov.uk/hadobs/hadisst/data/download.html</a> in netcdf format (the file HadISST_sst.nc.gz gunzipped).</p>

<p>It provides a simple function to load the netcdf data.</p>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-installation" class="anchor" href="#installation" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Installation</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>install.packages("ncdf")
install.packages("chron")

#install.packages("devtools")
library(devtools)
install_github("hadsstR", "jebyrnes")
</code></pre>

<pre lang="r,"><code>library(hadsstR)
</code></pre>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-loading-and-creating-derived-data-for-analysis" class="anchor" href="#loading-and-creating-derived-data-for-analysis" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Loading and Creating Derived Data for Analysis</h2>

<pre lang="r,"><code>library(hadsstR)
sstData &lt;- loadHadSST(directory="../", hadsstFilename="HadISST_sst.nc") 
summary(sstData)
</code></pre>

<p>One can then work with the dataset in a number of ways. For now, the functions all begin by creating annual averages, and working from there. The getClimateChange function generates a list of different matrices that can be used for further analyses of climate change.</p>

<pre lang="r,"><code>climateChangeMats &lt;- getClimateChange(sstData, years=1960:2009)
</code></pre>

<p>We can plot a number of derived quantities from this object. For example, average temperature over the timespan</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-c">#Let's plot some of these matrices</span>
<span class="pl-smi">pal</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> colorRampPalette(c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>blue<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>,<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>white<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>red<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))

with(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span>, image(<span class="pl-smi">lon</span>, <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, <span class="pl-smi">averageMat</span>, <span class="pl-v">col</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>pal(<span class="pl-c1">80</span>)))
</pre></div>

<p>Or the slope of the regression between temperature and year for each lat/long cell</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>library(<span class="pl-smi">lattice</span>)
<span class="pl-smi">latLonGrid</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> expand.grid(<span class="pl-v">lon</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">lon</span>, <span class="pl-v">lat</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">lat</span>)

levelplot(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">linearChangeMat</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lon</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, 
  <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">latLonGrid</span>, <span class="pl-v">col.regions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> pal(<span class="pl-c1">101</span>), <span class="pl-v">at</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>seq(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-c1">1</span>,<span class="pl-v">length.out</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">101</span>))</pre></div>

<p>We can look at spatial gradients in temperature</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-smi">pal2</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> colorRampPalette(c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>darkblue<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>blue<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>green<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>white<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>yellow<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>orange<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>red<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
with(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span>, image(<span class="pl-smi">lon</span>, <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, <span class="pl-smi">spatialGradMat</span>, <span class="pl-v">col</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>pal2(<span class="pl-c1">101</span>)))


<span class="pl-smi">palNS</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> colorRampPalette(c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>green<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>white<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>purple<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
levelplot(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">NSmat</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lon</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, <span class="pl-v">col.regions</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>palNS(<span class="pl-c1">100</span>),
          <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">latLonGrid</span>, <span class="pl-v">at</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>seq(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">0.03</span>, <span class="pl-c1">0.03</span>, <span class="pl-v">length.out</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">100</span>))

<span class="pl-smi">palWE</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> colorRampPalette(c(<span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>orange<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>white<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>blue<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>))
levelplot(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">WEmat</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lon</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, <span class="pl-v">col.regions</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>palWE(<span class="pl-c1">100</span>),
  <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">latLonGrid</span>, <span class="pl-v">at</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>seq(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">0.025</span>, <span class="pl-c1">0.025</span>, <span class="pl-v">length.out</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">100</span>))</pre></div>

<p>And with all of this, we can see climate change velocity</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre><span class="pl-c">#create a velocity matrix where values &gt;200 and &lt; -200 are truncated to those limits</span>
<span class="pl-c">#for easier plotting, as in Burrows et al. 20011</span>
<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span><span class="pl-k">$</span><span class="pl-smi">velocityMat</span>
<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span>[<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span> <span class="pl-k">&gt;</span><span class="pl-c1">200</span>] <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-c1">200</span>
<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span>[<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span> <span class="pl-k">&lt;</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">200</span>] <span class="pl-k">&lt;-</span> <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">200</span>

levelplot(<span class="pl-smi">velMatTruncated</span> <span class="pl-k">~</span> <span class="pl-smi">lon</span> <span class="pl-k">*</span> <span class="pl-smi">lat</span>, <span class="pl-v">data</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">latLonGrid</span>, <span class="pl-c">#at = cutpts, </span>
           <span class="pl-v">pretty</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> <span class="pl-c1">T</span>, 
          <span class="pl-v">col.regions</span> <span class="pl-k">=</span> pal(<span class="pl-c1">100</span>),
           <span class="pl-v">at</span><span class="pl-k">=</span>seq(<span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">200</span>,<span class="pl-c1">200</span>,<span class="pl-v">length.out</span><span class="pl-k">=</span><span class="pl-c1">100</span>))</pre></div>

<p>If we want to extract values for particular metrics at particular latitudes and longitudes, we can get the value at the closes lat/long in the data.</p>

<div class="highlight highlight-r"><pre>getClimateLatLon(<span class="pl-smi">climateChangeMats</span>, <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">50.232</span>, <span class="pl-k">-</span><span class="pl-c1">100.55</span>, <span class="pl-s"><span class="pl-pds">"</span>linearChange<span class="pl-pds">"</span></span>)</pre></div>

<p>Note that in the future I hope to add more functionality and deal with seasonal data. These methods <em>should</em> also work for other Hadley Centre data sets, but I have not yet tested them.</p>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-version-numbers" class="anchor" href="#version-numbers" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Version numbers</h2>

<p><code>hadsstR</code> uses <a href="http://semver.org/">semantic versioning</a>. The version numbering
scheme is <code>major</code>.<code>minor</code>.<code>revision</code>. Unless <code>major</code> is 1, the package
should not be considered stable. All releases with the same <code>major</code>
versions are compatible. Increases in <code>minor</code> represents the addition of
backwards-compatible additions. Increases in <code>revision</code> represents either
bug fixes or improvements.</p>

<h2>
<a id="user-content-contributions" class="anchor" href="#contributions" aria-hidden="true"><span class="octicon octicon-link"></span></a>Contributions</h2>

<p>People wanting to contribute are welcome to do so by forking the repository,
and submitting a pull request when their work is done. Please also edit the
<code>DESCRIPTION</code> file to add your name to the <code>Authors</code> field.</p>
</article>
